dispassionate.meaning_1: adjective: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.sentence_1: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

posit.sentence_1: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

misconstrue.meaning_1: verb: interpret in the wrong way
misconstrue.sentence_1: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

fastidious.meaning_1: adjective: overly concerned with details; fussy
fastidious.sentence_1: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

appease.meaning_1: verb: pacify by acceding to the demands of
appease.sentence_1: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

stringent.meaning_1: adjective: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
stringent.sentence_1: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

duress.sentence_1: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

askance.meaning_1: adverb: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
askance.sentence_1: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"

truncate.meaning_1: verb: reduce the length of something
truncate.sentence_1: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

harried.meaning_1: adjective: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
harried.sentence_1: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

mendacity.meaning_1: noun: the tendency to be untruthful
mendacity.sentence_1: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

opulence.meaning_1: noun: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opulence.sentence_1: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

edifying.meaning_1: adjective: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
edifying.sentence_1: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

capricious.meaning_1: adjective: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
capricious.sentence_1: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

dilatory.sentence_1: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

furtive.meaning_1: adjective: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
furtive.sentence_1: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

impartial.meaning_1: adjective: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
impartial.sentence_1: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

arduous.meaning_1: adjective: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
arduous.sentence_1: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

Magoosh Score Estimator.meaning_1: noun: After taking a practice exam, determine your score on the GRE 340-point scale. Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Score Estimator.sentence_1: Mike scored a 335 on a practice exam using the Magoosh score estimator.

indecorous.meaning_1: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
indecorous.sentence_1: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

polemic.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
polemic.meaning_1: noun: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.sentence_1: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

imprudent.sentence_1: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

sullen.meaning_1: adjective: showing a brooding ill humor
sullen.sentence_1: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

flux.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
flux.meaning_1: noun: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
flux.sentence_1: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

transient.meaning_1: adjective: lasting a very short time
transient.sentence_1: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

economical.sentence_1: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

maverick.meaning_1: noun: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
maverick.sentence_1: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

reproach.sentence_1: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

bolster.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
bolster.sentence_1: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

deleterious.sentence_1: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

timorous.meaning_1: adjective: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
timorous.sentence_1: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

contrition.meaning_1: noun: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
contrition.sentence_1: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.

esoteric.meaning_1: adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.sentence_1: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

antipathy.meaning_1: noun: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
antipathy.sentence_1: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

disseminate.meaning_1: verb: cause to become widely known
disseminate.sentence_1: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

elicit.meaning_1: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
elicit.sentence_1: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

specious.sentence_1: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.
specious.sentence_2: He made a career out of specious arguments and fictional lab results, but lost his job and reputation when his lies were exposed by an article in The New York Times.
specious.meaning_1: adjective: based on pretense; deceptively pleasing

rebuke.meaning_1: verb: criticize severely or angrily; censure
rebuke.sentence_1: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

nonplussed.meaning_1: adjective: unsure how to act or respond
nonplussed.sentence_1: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

mundane.sentence_1: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.
mundane.sentence_2: Though we think of the pope as someone always dealing in holy matters, he is also concerned with mundane events, such as deciding when to set his alarm each morning.
mundane.meaning_2: adjective: relating to the ordinary world
mundane.meaning_1: adjective: repetitive and boring; not spiritual

nuance.meaning_1: noun: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.sentence_1: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

maladroit.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
maladroit.sentence_1: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

erudite.meaning_1: adjective: having or showing profound knowledge
erudite.sentence_1: Before the Internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

ignominious.meaning_1: adjective: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.sentence_1: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

efficacious.sentence_1: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

jovial.meaning_1: adjective: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
jovial.sentence_1: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

pejorative.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pejorative.meaning_1: adjective: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.sentence_1: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

anomaly.meaning_1: noun: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
anomaly.sentence_1: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

craven.sentence_1: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

placate.meaning_1: verb: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
placate.sentence_1: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

banality.meaning_1: noun: a trite or obvious remark
banality.sentence_1: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.
